document.masterDocTitle: Potamocloeon edentatum sp. n. from Usambara Mountains in Tanzania (Ephemeroptera, Baetidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Potamocloeon edentatum sp. n. from Usambara Mountains in Tanzania (Ephemeroptera, Baetidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology. Allusion to absence of the tooth-like projection on the gonostylus, in contrast to
Potamocloeon dentatum
, which is characterized by «inner basal angle dilated to form a strong tooth» ( Kimmins 1956: 76 ).

Material examined.
Holotype :
L-S-I ♂ {specimen [XL](4)2016}, TANZANIA , Tanga Region , Usambara mountains , Amani , upper part of river Sigi , 5°06’S , 38°38’E ,
3.IX.2016
, coll. N. Kluge & L. Sheyko.
Paratypes :
the same locality and collectors,
19.VIII–2.IX.2016
, 2 L-S-I ♂
, 1 L-S ♂ , 4 L/S ♂ , 2 L-S-I ♀ , 1 L/S ♀ , 23 larvae .
HYPODERMAL COLORATION. Usually invisible through cuticular coloration ( Fig. 14 ); if visible, abdominal coloration similar to that of imago (compare Figs 15 and 61 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 14–23. Larvae of
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 14, male larva of last instar with well-developed cuticular coloration; 15, female larva of penultimate instar with light cuticle and well-visible hypodermal coloration; 16, exuviae of fore leg with prothoracic pleurite; 17, exuviae of middle leg; 18, exuviae of hind leg with metathoracic pleurite and part of metanotum (arrow shows vestige of hind protopteron); 19, exuviae of abdomen; 20, exuviae of right half of pronotum and mesonotum; 21, head; 22, portion of cercus and paracercus in middle part; 23, apices of cercus and paracercus.

FIGURES 24–27. Larvae of
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 24, maxilla (ventral view); 25, left half of labrum (dorsal view); 26–27, apices of left and right mandibles before molt to next larval instar. Abbreviations: ds1–ds3, dentisetae.

FIGURES 28–36. Larvae of
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 28, 29, tergalii of 1st pair; 30–35, tergalii of 2nd–7th pairs; 36, labium (at left ventral view and musculature, at right dorsal view).

FIGURES 37–44. Larvae of
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 37, fore leg (dorsal view); 38, articulation of femur and tibia of middle leg (dorsal view); 39, fragment of fore tarsus (ventral view); 40, fragment of middle tarsus (ventral view); 41–42, claws; 43, exuviae of paraprocts and protogonostyli of male larva; 44, exuviae of 9th and 10th terga.

FIGURES 45–51. Larval legs of
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. (instead of long hairs, only their bases are shown as small rings). 45, fore femur (dorsal view); 46, middle femur (dorsal view); 47, fore tibia (anterior view); 48, middle tibia (anterior view); 49, hind tibia (anterior view); 50, fore tarsus (dorsal view), 51, middle tarsus (dorsal view).

FIGURES 52–55. Larval abdominal sterna of
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 52, halves of abdominal sterna II–VIII; 53, frag- ment of sternum III; 54, fragment of sternum V; 55, fragment of sternum VII.

FIGURES 56–62.
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 56, abdominal terga of male imago; 57–59, male imagines; 60, abdominal sterna of male imago; 61–62, female imago (56, 60, holotype).

FIGURES 63–69.
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 63, subimaginal exuviae of tibia and tarsus of female fore leg; 64, the same, hind leg; 65, its imaginal hind leg; 66, subimaginal exuviae of mesopleuron; 67, subimaginal exuviae of left half of mesonotum; 68–69, genitals of male imagines (66–68, holotype).

FIGURES 70–72.
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 70, subimaginal exuviae of gonostyli; 71, genitals of male imago (gonostylar muscle shown only on right side, gonovectal muscles shown only on left side, gonoducts shown by dotted line); 72, larval protogonostyli with developing subimaginal genitas inside. Abbreviations: gs1–gs3, segments of gonostylus; m.IX-X, areas of anterior attachment of median paraproctal muscles (i.e., muscles going from sternum IX to common base of paraprocts); m.sg, median sterno-styligeral muscle; pgs, protogonostylus; usg, unistyliger.

FIGURES 73–76.
Potamocloeon edentatum
sp. n. 73–75, eggs; 76, tergalius IV.

subSubSection.paragraph: RESPIRATORY MOVEMENTS. Tergalii able to make rhythmic respiratory movements.
TEXTURE. On legs of all pairs of both sexes, all tarsal segments covered by pointed microlepides, only small basal part of fore tarsomere covered by microtrichia (as tibia and other leg segments).

Imago, male .
( Figs 56–60 ). Head ocher with brown. Turbinate eyes with facetted surface and most part of stem brown, upper part of stem just under facetted surface gray, border between stem and facetted surface dark brown. Thorax brown, uniformly colored dorsally, laterally and ventrally. Fore wing with one marginal intercalary per space; pterostigma with 3–5 simple, oblique, complete or/and incomplete veins ( Fig. 13 ); bases of wings brownish, remainder colorless; veins, including costal brace, colorless. Hind wings absent. Legs of all pairs either uniformly ocher, or with diffusive reddish markings as in Fig. 65 . On middle and hind legs tibia slightly shorter than tarsus; first tarsomere (primary 1st+2nd tarsomeres) much longer than others (as in Fig. 65 ). In holotype , relation of fore femur to fore wing length 40:195; proportions femur/tibia/tarsomeres on fore leg 40:49:2:26:20:10:5; on middle and hind legs 30:25:9:4:2:5. Tarsus with one terminal spine on 2nd (primary 3rd tarsomere) tarsomere (as in Fig. 64 ). Abdominal segments I–VII whitish; terga either without markings, or each tergum with diffusive pale reddish unpaired median mark; sterna either without markings, or with small gray unpaired median spot on each joining of segments ( Fig. 60 ); lateral trachea with blackish. Segments VIII–IX with terga brown, sterna whitish, anteriorly bordered by brown; segment X brown. Cerci uniformly whitish.

Eggs .
Irregularly oval, with irregular relief ( Figs 73–76 ).
Dimensions. Fore wing length (and body length) 4.5–5 mm .

Comparison. Male imago of
P. edentatum
sp. n. differs from
P. dentatum
(=
plumosum
) by shape of first segment of gonostylus, whose inner-distal angle is blunt and not projected distally ( Figs 68, 69 , 71 ). Larva of
P. edentatum
sp. n. differs by having first pair of tergalii asymmetric ( Figs 28–29 ), while in
P. dentatum
first tergalius is symmetric, with both costal and anal margins most convex in proximal half (Wuillot & Gillies 1993: fig. 49); in
P. abdallahi
the shape of tergalii is said to be «as per Wuillot & Gillies (1993)» (McCafferty 2000: 68). Besides this, larva of
P. edentatum
sp. n. differs from
P. dentatum
and
P. abdallahi
by absence of prominent setae between prostheca and mola of left mandible ( Fig. 26 ). Larvae of
P. edentatum
sp. n. and
P. dentatum
differ from
P. abdallahi
by well pigmented tracheae of tergalii ( Figs 28–30 ).
